meaning_mnemonic: You have two lines with legs below them. And what is that bit above the legs? Well, it's where you came from — your <radical>origin</radical>. Yep, between two legs is where you originated, no matter how you look at it.

Have you ever used one of those triangular rulers? This looks just like one of those, because this is the <radical>measurement</radical> radical. Just think of all the angles you could measure with this thing!

This radical technically means person (like 人), but we're going to shift the meaning a little bit. It's kind of like the person radical, but it's taller and skinnier, standing above the others and raising its fist to lead them. That's why this is a <radical>leader</radical>, not a regular person.

Sure, this <radical>forehead</radical> is a bit square, but that's because it's the top part of the head (冂) radical. This is just the forehead part of that! You can even imagine this as the forehead of Frankenstein's monster, since his forehead was pretty square too.

Also, don't confuse this for a roof. You know this is a forehead and not a roof because this doesn't have a cute little chimney sticking out of the top. Foreheads definitely don't have chimneys.
See the mouth and long, fang-like teeth of this <radical>alligator</radical>, which is facing to the right? You wouldn't want to get your hand stuck in there, that's for sure.

This radical looks like a person with a long dress running behind them. That's because they're all dressed up to go to a <radical>ceremony</radical>. You usually have to wear a long dress (or something formal) if you're going to a big ceremony, right? So when you see this radical, think of all the different ceremonies you might have to go to in your life and what you'll need to wear.

This radical looks like some sort of <radical>spirit</radical>. It faces to the left with a big hood over its head, and creepy arms slanting downward at the sides. Can you picture it?

If not, just think of this as the katakana character for "ne." Ne for necromancer, bringing back spirits from the grave! OooooOOoooOoo!

There's a cross branching off of this stool. Since it's branching out, we'll just call this the <radical>branch</radical> radical. I guess the tree this stool was made of is coming back to life in the form of a branch.

This is the radical for <radical>energy</radical>. If you imagine a train under this radical, then the lines would be steam bursting out of it, flowing back from the front of the train (on the left) as it goes chugging along. Steam was the best way to generate energy back in the day, you know? That's why this is the radical for energy.

Use your imagination to draw a circle outside this shape. The grids from the radical start to look like longitude and latitude lines on a globe, don't they? That's why this is the <radical>world</radical>.

This is a few plates drying on a rack. They're stacked together in a line. Imagine reaching out and grabbing one of those plates for yourself. And you only need one, so let's call this radical <radical>plate</radical>.
See how tall the stalks are with little bushy things at the top? It kind of looks like <radical>bamboo</radical>, if you use your imagination.

In some poop you find something small. You lean in, carefully pull it out, and realize it's a <radical>thread</radical>. What's that doing there? Well, it came from a cat, and cats love to eat thread when you aren't looking. And floss and hoodie strings and mouse tails… But this time, just thread.

This is the <radical>ear</radical> radical, since it looks like an ear. As much as a radical can, anyway. Those two middle lines are the ridges that guide the sound into your ear, and the lines that stick out to the right are where the ear attaches to your head.

If you think about it, ears are just eyes that see sound. Whoa, dude… That explains the eye (目) and ear (耳) radical resemblance. Just remember this one is "ear" because ears stick out, just like the lines sticking out of the side of this radical.

This looks like the middle radical on top of a sideways leaf. What can you often find sitting on the middle of a leaf? An <radical>insect</radical>. Insects looove sitting right in the middle of leaves. That's why this is the insect radical.

See the little things sticking out of the ground? Those little things are pretty little <radical>flowers</radical>.

You could also see this as a little flower crown, especially since this radical almost always appears at the top of a kanji.

This eye has legs, since you have to let your eyes run over something in order to <radical>see</radical> it. That's why those eyes need legs — to see. They're wandering eyes, they want to see the world!!

A pile of dirt fell on you and now your legs and (scuba) fins are sticking out from under it, turning <radical>red</radical>. You know, because you've been stuck in the sun so long. Everything's all sunburned and red. Can scuba fins get a sunburn? Yeah, when it's red hot outside. That's why this means "red."

Doesn't this look like a top-down view of the frame of a <radical>car</radical>? There are the axles at the top and bottom, and the body in the middle between them. That's why this is the car radical.

This radical looks like a <radical>shellfish</radical>. What looks like the eye radical is its long spiral shell. The bottom part that looks like fins is its little legs poking out, helping the shellfish move around.

This is the <radical>foot</radical> radical. See the person doing a flying dragon kick to the right? What do they hit the target with? Obviously their foot. Imagine that foot coming straight at your face. At that point, your only hope is that it's clean. Nobody wants a foot to the face, especially not a filthy foot.

This looks like a regular arrow, but it's not. Let's call it the "not arrow." It can not move forward, because it's been stopped by some kind of line above it. Every arrow wants to fly, but this one is not going anywhere. Look at it, being all negated like that. Well, that's just what this radical does. It nots things.

The <radical>samurai</radical> radical looks a lot like the dirt radical. The difference is this one has a longer top horizontal line, which is for those broad warrior shoulders. The bottom line is also shorter, since it's the little cushion the samurai is sitting on. Samurai didn't just fight, you know. They sat on cushions and wrote poems and stuff too. This is a very sensitive samurai.

This is the radical for <radical>rice</radical>. Specifically raw rice, like the grain that grows out of the ground when rice is raw and fresh. When rice is particularly ripe, it'll kind of look like this at the top of the stalks. See the long leaves and the little rice tufts at the top? That's why this radical is "rice."

The leader (ｲ) radical has a little something extra on top of him — he's got a casual cap on because it's his day off. And what does he like to do on his day off? He likes to <radical>loiter</radical>. Look at him just loitering around. What a loiterer.

You'll have to complete the line on the right side in your mind, but see the rectangle <radical>bed</radical> and the pillows? This is totally a bed. That missing line is where you pulled back the covers when you got up this morning.
Obviously, this looks just like the good ol' 3.14 something-something all people are supposed to learn about. It's the math symbol that has to do with circles... <radical>pi</radical>!
See the <radical>cliff</radical>? It's facing to the left. What do you think this cliff is jutting out over? Maybe an ocean, or a valley? Cliffs love to jut out over things like that.

The king is hovering a drop of water over his head. He's acquired the ability to manipulate water at will, making him the <radical>master</radical> of all water! If you think about how all life depends on water, that really makes him the master of everything…

You have a roof on top of what looks like a volcano. What's the roof covering? It's definitely covering the hole at the top. I guess someone thought if they built a roof on the hole, none of the lava could come out. But isn't there a hole in the chimney? Guess their theory had some holes in it… Oh no, now lava is coming through the hole. RUN!!! RUN!!!!!!!!
This radical looks like an <radical>umbrella</radical>, specifically just the handle part. A good old curvy umbrella handle, so you can hang that umbrella on your arm when it stops raining.

Remember the guy from the big radical? Here he's bending his arms up to fasten some kind of belt, right across the <radical>center</radical> of his body. It's one of those belts that just goes across your waist, which is actually perfect for such a big guy, since he really needs to secure his center (of gravity).

A rice paddy needs power, and that power comes from a <radical>man</radical>. Picture a rice paddy full of thick, wet mud. It's no easy field to work in, but this powerful man will bend over to rake and hoe tirelessly to make sure it thrives. What a man!

Doesn't this look like someone on their knees, holding their clasped hands out and begging for something (forgiveness, their life, a promotion, etc.)? That's why this radical is known as the <radical>beggar</radical>.
Can you see the <radical>horns</radical>? You could put these horns on anything. Donkeys, people, monkeys, and so on. That's exactly what we'll be doing when we learn kanji that have horns too.
On the ground there are a bunch of <radical>spikes</radical> coming out. You wouldn't want to step on those now, would you?
